title: The Impact Of Winter Inactivity On Digestion And Stomach Cancer Recovery - News18
summary:
The Impact of Winter Inactivity on Digestion and Stomach Cancer Recovery

Publication Date: December 22, 2024 | Source: News18

Winter can significantly slow down digestive processes and hinder recovery for stomach cancer patients due to reduced physical activity and increased inflammation.

  • Stomach cancer patients face additional challenges during winter.
  • Physical inactivity weakens immune function, crucial for recovery.
  • Winter leads to slower metabolism and suboptimal nutritional intake.
  • Regular exercise can improve gut motility and reduce inflammation.
Dr. Neeraj Goel, Director, Oncology Services, states that an inflamed gut creates a negative feedback loop, impacting overall health.

Proactive measures such as regular exercise and a nutrient-rich diet can help mitigate the effects of winter on digestion and recovery.
newTitle: The Impact of Winter Inactivity on Digestion and Stomach Cancer Recovery

title: 9 Warning Signs Of Pre-Diabetes - India.Com
summary:
9 Warning Signs Of Pre-Diabetes

Publication Date: December 22, 2024 Source: India.com

This article highlights the key warning signs that may indicate pre-diabetes, a serious health condition that can lead to type 2 diabetes if not monitored and managed properly.

  • Dark skin areas in the neck or armpits may signal insulin resistance.
  • Excessive thirst without physical activity can indicate high blood sugar.
  • Increased urination frequency may suggest blood sugar imbalance.
  • Unexplained tiredness could indicate difficulty in processing glucose.
  • Slow healing of cuts and bruises may reflect poor blood sugar control.
  • Unexpected weight changes might be related to blood sugar fluctuations.
  • Blurred vision can occur due to high blood sugar affecting eyesight.
  • Frequent infections can be linked to weakened immunity from high blood sugar.
  • Tingling or numbness in extremities may indicate nerve damage caused by high glucose.

Monitoring these symptoms and consulting with a healthcare professional is crucial for early intervention and management of pre-diabetes.
newTitle: 9 Warning Signs Of Pre-Diabetes

title: Heart muscle can regenerate after failure in some patients with artificial hearts: Study - Mathrubhumi English
summary:
Heart Muscle Can Regenerate After Failure in Some Patients with Artificial Hearts: Study

Published on: IANS

A groundbreaking study has revealed that heart muscle can regenerate in certain patients with artificial hearts, offering new hope for treating and potentially curing heart failure.

  • A subset of patients with artificial hearts demonstrated significant heart muscle regeneration.
  • Heart failure traditionally has no cure, with limited treatment options available.
  • Patients with artificial hearts regenerated heart muscle cells at a rate more than six times higher than healthy individuals.
  • Research emphasizes the need for heart muscle to rest to enhance regenerative capacity.
  • Collaboration between the University of Arizona and the University of Utah was critical to the study.
  • The findings were published in the journal Circulation.
“This is the strongest evidence we have so far that human heart muscle cells can actually regenerate,” said Dr. Sadek.

This discovery could lead to innovative therapies aimed at repairing damaged heart tissue and potentially curing heart failure.
newTitle: Heart Muscle Regeneration Possible in Some Patients with Artificial Hearts

title: Breastfeeding and breast cancer: A natural defense you should know about - India Today
summary:
Breastfeeding and breast cancer: A natural defense you should know about

Published On: Dec 22, 2024  Source: Indiatoday

Breastfeeding offers powerful health benefits for mothers, including a reduced risk of breast cancer by changing hormonal exposures and breast tissue composition. The longer one breastfeeds, the greater the protective effects, though even short-term breastfeeding can be beneficial.

  • Breastfeeding lowers breast cancer risk through hormonal changes.
  • Self-examinations for breast cancer should be done monthly.
  • Annual mammograms should start at age 30.
  • Lifestyle factors, such as diet and exercise, influence breast cancer risk.
  • Breastfeeding not only benefits the baby but also provides lasting health advantages for mothers.
“Yes, breastfeeding can help reduce the risk of breast cancer. Studies have shown that women who breastfeed have a lower risk of developing breast cancer compared to those who do not.”

In conclusion, breastfeeding emerges not only as a nurturing practice but also as a vital health strategy that can significantly reduce the risk of breast cancer in women.
newTitle: Breastfeeding as a Natural Defense Against Breast Cancer

title: 10 diet practices to control cholesterol level - The Times of India
summary:
10 Diet Practices to Control Cholesterol Levels

Publication Date: Dec 22, 2024 | Source: Times of India

Maintaining cholesterol levels is key to reducing heart disease and stroke. A healthy level of cholesterol aids in good blood flow, preserves arteries and helps ensure long-term cardiovascular health. Here is how you can control cholesterol through diet.

  • Consume healthy vegetable oils like canola, sunflower, or safflower.
  • Fresh fruits and vegetables are low in calories and rich in antioxidants and fiber.
  • Avoid alcohol consumption and smoking to protect heart health.
  • Incorporate cholesterol-lowering spices such as turmeric, garlic, and ginger.
  • Replace red meat with fat-free proteins, including fish and legumes.
  • Consume 25 grams of soy protein daily to potentially lower LDL cholesterol.
  • Include foods fortified with plant sterols and stanols in your diet.
  • Eat more whole grains like brown rice and quinoa for essential nutrients and fiber.
  • Incorporate fatty fish into your diet to provide omega-3s, reducing triglycerides.
"Maintaining cholesterol levels is key to reducing heart disease and stroke."

This article emphasizes the importance of dietary choices in controlling cholesterol levels, thereby supporting cardiovascular health.
newTitle: 10 Diet Practices to Control Cholesterol Levels

Are You Brushing Enough? Know the Risks for Head and Neck Cancer

Publication Date: December 17, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses the relationship between oral hygiene habits and the risk of head and neck cancers, emphasizing key symptoms and contributing factors.

  • Understanding head and neck cancer along with its key symptoms includes persistent sore throat, voice changes, and swallowing difficulties.
  • Major contributors to these cancers are tobacco, betelnut, and alcohol, with 80% of cases linked to these habits.
  • Poor dental hygiene practices in India are significant contributors to oral cancers.
  • Delayed detection often leads to advanced stages requiring complex and costly treatments.
  • Early signs such as abnormal growths and persistent symptoms should prompt medical consultation.
“Watch for abnormal growths, gum bleeding, persistent voice changes, difficulty swallowing, or neck lumps. Early consultation can save lives.”

In conclusion, maintaining regular dental hygiene and being aware of the early signs of head and neck cancer can significantly impact prevention and outcomes.

title: ‘Faster walkers’ had significantly lower risk of diabetes, hypertension: Study - The Tribune India
summary:
Faster Walkers Have Lower Risk of Diabetes and Hypertension, Study Reveals

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Tribune

This study reveals that individuals with faster walking speeds are at a significantly lower risk of metabolic conditions like diabetes and hypertension. Conducted by researchers from Japan, the findings suggest that even those with obesity can reduce their risks by improving their walking pace.

  1. Study involved nearly 25,000 participants with obesity or high waist circumference.
  2. Faster walkers showed approximately 30% lower risk of diabetes.
  3. Notable reductions were also observed in hypertension and dyslipidemia risks.
  4. The findings link walking speed to overall health, particularly cardiorespiratory fitness.
  5. Subjective walking speed could be easily integrated into health assessments.
  6. Study emphasizes the value of promoting faster walking as a preventative measure for metabolic diseases.
“This study clarified that even individuals with obesity, who are at higher risk for metabolic diseases, have lower odds of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia if they report a fast subjective walking speed.” - Kojiro Ishii, lead researcher

The study indicates that quick assessments of walking speed can help identify individuals at risk for metabolic disorders, particularly beneficial in healthcare settings.
newTitle: Faster Walkers Have Lower Risk of Diabetes and Hypertension, Study Reveals

title: Health warning issued over flesh-eating ulcer in Australia - The Statesman
AIIMS Doctors In Process Of Developing Low-Cost Cellular Therapy For Multiple Myeloma - Times Now
summary:
AIIMS Doctors In Process Of Developing Low-Cost Cellular Therapy For Multiple Myeloma

Date: October 2023 | Source: Times Now

Doctors at AIIMS, Delhi, are developing a cost-effective antibody-based adaptive cellular therapy for treating multiple myeloma, aiming to make advanced treatments like CAR-T cell therapy more affordable for Indian patients.

  • The therapy targets B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA) in multiple myeloma cells.
  • Research shows promising results in animal models, with plans for phase-1 clinical trials ahead.
  • Current CAR-T cell therapies are prohibitively expensive in India.
  • According to the National Cancer Registry, India had 14,61,427 new cancer cases in 2022, highlighting the need for accessible treatment options.
“Immunotherapies have the potential to transform cancer treatment, but their high cost limits their reach. Our work at AIIMS is focused on addressing this gap by developing affordable alternatives.” - Dr. Mayank Singh

The progress made by AIIMS researchers is a hopeful step towards improving cancer treatment accessibility in India, particularly for multiple myeloma patients.
newTitle: AIIMS Develops Affordable Cellular Therapy for Multiple Myeloma

title: Journal finally retracts the discredited hydroxychloroquine paper - The Hindu
summary:
Journal Finally Retracts Discredited Hydroxychloroquine Study

Published Date: December 21, 2024

Source: The Hindu

The study by Didier Raoult and colleagues, published in March 2020, claimed hydroxychloroquine was effective against COVID-19. This paper has now been retracted due to serious ethical concerns.

  • The controversial study was published on March 20, 2020, and retracted on December 17, 2024.
  • The paper claimed hydroxychloroquine significantly reduced viral load in COVID-19 patients.
  • It triggered widespread use and approval of the drug despite insufficient evidence supporting its effectiveness.
  • Concerns were raised about the study's methodology and ethical approval.
  • The journal expressed doubts but did not retract the paper until now, following new investigations initiated by the authors themselves.
The journal has not been able to establish whether all patients could have entered into the study in time for the data to have been analyzed and included in the manuscript prior to its submission.

The retraction serves as a critical reminder of the importance of rigorous peer review and ethical standards in medical research.
newTitle: Journal Finally Retracts Discredited Hydroxychloroquine Study

What happens to your body in space? 5 surprising NASA facts - Hindustan Times
summary:
What happens to your body in space? 5 surprising NASA facts

Publication Date: December 18, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

This article explores the surprising effects of space travel on the human body, based on studies conducted by NASA in preparation for future missions to the Moon and Mars.

  • NASA studies how space impacts human health to prepare for future Moon and Mars missions.
  • Astronauts face health challenges, including bone density loss of 1-1.5% per month in microgravity.
  • Fluid shifts in microgravity can lead to increased pressure on the eyes and vision problems.
  • Dehydration and calcium loss increase the risk of kidney stones in space.
  • Astronauts learn to create medical solutions and perform health checks using ultrasound during missions.
Astronauts lose about 1-1.5% of bone density per month during spaceflight.

The findings underscore the importance of further research into the effects of long-duration space travel on health as humanity aims for deeper space exploration.
newTitle: What happens to your body in space? 5 surprising NASA facts

title: 'Faster walkers' are at significantly lower risk of diabetes, hypertension: Study - Deccan Herald
summary:
Faster walkers' are at significantly lower risk of diabetes, hypertension: Study

Published Date: 22 December 2024, Source: Deccan Herald

This study conducted by researchers from Doshisha University in Japan found that individuals who perceive themselves to walk faster than their peers are at a significantly lower risk of metabolic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension.

  • The study involved nearly 25,000 participants with obesity or high waist circumference.
  • Faster walkers exhibited about a 30% lower risk for diabetes.
  • There were notable reductions in risks for hypertension and dyslipidemia.
  • The findings suggest a link between walking speed and overall health due to better cardiorespiratory fitness.
  • The study indicates a simple health questionnaire can aid in identifying at-risk individuals.
  • Lead researcher Kojiro Ishii emphasized the importance of walking pace in preventing metabolic diseases.
"Promoting a faster walking pace may be a helpful individual behaviour to help prevent metabolic diseases, particularly in individuals with obesity," - Kojiro Ishii

This research highlights that subjective walking speed is a valuable and easily implemented health assessment tool, especially relevant for obesity management.
newTitle: Faster walkers at lower risk of diabetes and hypertension, study reveals

title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
summary:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics for easier recall of information.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention."

By incorporating these tips into daily routines, individuals can enhance their cognitive ability and maintain sharper memories as they age.
newTitle: 7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age
